content.description: A proud line up the central Heart Cave pillar. Climb rough crimps up the steepening bulge, eventually groping the polished prow, followed by a lunge for a sinker pocket at the bottom of the polished, gray water scoop at the 15 foot level. Finish up the slippery scoop.
content.location: Left side of the Heart Cave pillar, opposite the Heart Cave Problem.

content.description: Walking left from the Heart Cave, you will pass a short boulder that seems unremarkable until you walk around its left side. An excellent traverse starts low on the left, follows positive edges on the lip, and tops out on the right end of the boulder.
content.protection: Pads are nice, but it's low with a soft landing.

content.description: A neat hidden problem on a steep, rounded prow that features a big sloper and a committing finish to the tip of the prow. The landing area is enclosed by steep walls, adding considerable fear factor to an already highball endeavor. Luckily, the holds lead the climber directly over the tight landing zone. A beautiful moderate classic requiring some boldness.
content.protection: Many pads are a good idea, for protection and for keeping your feet dry, though it's been done several times with no pad. Spotters will give confidence for the committing high finish.
content.location: Directly above the Heart Cave about 50 feet. Pumping Romex climbs out of a deep, dark cavern cut by the same water that drains down into the Heart Cave. To get there, climb padless straight out the Heart Cave through a v1 face to chimney hole then scramble straight up for 50 feet, or hike with your pad starting to the right of the Heart Cave. The problem is invisible until you can peer down on it from above through a deep slot.

content.description: The hardest and best problem on the Heart Cave Boulder. Start with good edges and big feet just to the right of the V3 arête and head for the bowl at the lip. Top out direct.
content.location: On the side of the Heart Cave Boulder that faces the cliff, just to the right of an arête.

content.description: Named in memory of Jimmy the Jet Gaun. Start on the prow feature, follow a series of opposing holds to a large pocket. From the pocket traverse left to the arete over a conspicuous landing and finally up on easier terrain.
content.location: From the heart cave boulder look up and left and this problem is perched on a small rock ledge.

content.description: The direct line up the Heart Cave, avoiding the broken jugs of the standard start, is stellar. Begin on low sloping sidepulls, bump left to a positive slot and make some powerful moves straight up to the jug horn, then continue through the committing topout of the standard Heart Cave problem.
content.protection: A few pads are very helpful for the topout.
content.location: On the column in the Heart Cave, climb direct to the horn.

content.description: A good highball on a very unique boulder. Begin sitting at a shelf low and right. Trend up and left past slopers and a flake to gain the huge holds atop the block, then continue moving up and left through crimpy, very committing moves to a relatively simple rockover well off the deck. Originally, the problem ended at the buckets on the block. V4 and still worth doing if you're not up to the scary exit.
content.protection: Multiple pads and an attentive spotter.
content.location: Climbs out the right side of the huge alien-head/mushroom boulder in the center of the Heart Cave. Follow the chalk.

content.description: Step onto the slab and palm/mantel for a distant hueco. A good balance test.
content.location: Climbs up the slabby side of the Heart Cave Boulder to the obvious hole. Tricky exit off the cliff-facing side of the boulder.

content.description: Start as low as you can and paddle your way up the rounded arête until you can roll over and top out. A bit awkward, but fun nonetheless.
content.location: On the left side of the Heart Cave Boulder, to the left of the slab problem. Tricky exit off the cliff-facing side of the boulder.

content.description: Climb slick patina sidepulls and pinches to a big move to the lip. Be nice to the tree.
content.location: On the right (closest to the cave) face of the Heart Cave Boulder. Tricky exit off the cliff-facing side of the boulder.

content.description: An eliminate, but a good one: start on crimps on the west face and use poor feet to lunge to the obvious jug at the lip. Originally rated B1+
content.location: West face of the Heart Cave Boulder, adjacent arete is off.

content.description: Start on good edges and climb the northeast arete of the boulder with technical moves between mostly good holds, over a truly awful landing. Pad and spot carefully!
content.location: Northeast arete of the Heart Cave Boulder.

content.description: Climb the wall in the back of the Heart Cave on good holds, then follow the chimney to daylight.
content.protection: A pad if you want, for the starting moves. Don't fall out of the chimney.

content.description: Start on an undercling and shoot up left to a small triangle crimp/pinch. Use small edges, delicate footwork, and a lot of core tension to gain the slab.
content.location: Outside the heart cave to the right.

content.description: On the boulder spray-painted with "A.C.": climb the center of the bulge starting at round slopers, pulling with difficulty to small crimps at the lip and continuing up with an easier topout on the slab. Starting on the high lip holds and finishing the same is a decent V3.
content.protection: Good landing, one pad should suffice.
content.location: Walk a bit left from the Heart Cave and look for the boulder spray-painted "A.C." just off the base of the cliffs.

content.description: The first area reached at Gloria's, named for the decades-old broken heart graffiti at the back of the cave (regrettably painted over in recent years.) A popular drop-off/highball problem ascends the right side of the mushroom-shaped center column. There are many fine problems on the boulders surrounding the cave, especially the Heart Cave Boulder directly to the left.
